title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
1. Introduction

In comparative judgments (CJ) studies [1, 2]




judges assess a specific trait or attribute
across different stimuli
by performing pairwise comparisons
producing a dichotomous outcome




e.g., when assessing writing quality, judges compare pairs of written texts (the stimuli) to determine the relative writing quality each text exhibit (the trait)

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
1. Introduction

Literature have documented the effectiveness of CJ on three aspects:


Reliability
Validity
Practical applicability




But the methodology have some issues …


Result on reliability:

CJ needs a modest number of pairwise comparisons [3, 4]
CJ can generate precise and consistent trait scores compared to other assessment methods [5–7].
CJ has equal, if not superior, time efficiency than other assessment methods when employing adaptive comparison algorithms [8–10].

Result on validity:

CJ scores represent accurately the traits under measurement [7, 11–14].

Result on practical applicability:

CJ is versatile across both educational and non-educational contexts [14–20].

3.2 Measurement and hypothesis tests
Researchers use the BTL model as a measurement model for CJ [5–8, 11–13, 25], i.e., they use the estimated BTL scores, or their transformations, to conduct additional analyses or hypothesis tests, for example:



Identify ‘misfit’ judges and stimuli [6, 8, 12]
Detect biases in judges’ ratings [8, 26]
Calculate correlations with other assessment methods [6, 7],
Test hypotheses related to the underlying trait of interest [7, 17, 20, 27–30]

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
4. Extending Thurstone’s theory

We use the structural approach to causal inference [33–36] to formally and graphically representing the assumed (causal) structure of the CJ system. Specifically we use:


Structural Causal Models (SCMs) and
Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs)





Essentially, SCMs and DAGs function as conceptual models on which identification analysis rests [37].
Identification analysis helps researchers to determine whether an estimator can accurately compute an estimand based solely on its (causal) assumptions, regardless of random variability [37].
Identification is crucial because it is a necessary condition for ensuring consistent estimators.
Consistency refers to the property of an estimator whose estimates converge to the “true” value of the estimand as the data size approaches infinity [38].
Without identification, consistency cannot be achieved, even with “infinite” and error-free data. Thus, deriving meaningful insights from finite data becomes impossible [37].

4. Extending Thurstone’s theory

Motivating example: “To what extent do different teaching methods influence students’ ability to produce high-quality written texts?”


Solution: Researchers design a CJ experiment.


Assume:



researcher randomly assign students to two groups, each receiving a different teaching method.
judges then compare pairs of students’ written texts
judges produce a dichotomous outcome, reflecting the relative quality of each text

Assuming we have access to comparison data from a conceptual population, that is, data representing:




all repeated judgments
made by every available judge
for each pair of stimuli
produced by each pair of individuals

\(n_{A}\) denotes the number of stimuli available per individual
\(n_{J}\) indicates the total number of judges, and
\(n_{K}\) represents the number of judgments each judge performs

5. Abandoning the BTL model









\[
\begin{aligned}
  O_{RPUV} & = O^{sc}_{RPUV} \odot C \\
  O^{sc}_{RPUV} & = O^{cp}_{RPUV} \odot S_{RPUV} \\
  O^{cp}_{RPUV} & \sim \text{Bernoulli} \left[ \text{inv_logit}( D_{RPUV} ) \right] \\
  D_{RPUV} & = \left( T_{IA}[R_{1},P_{1}] - T_{IA}[R_{2},P_{2}] \right) + B_{JK}[U,V] \\
  T_{IA} & = T_{I} + \beta_{XA} X_{IA} + e_{IA} \\
  T_{I} & = \beta_{XI} X_{I} + e_{I} \\
  B_{JK} & = B_{J} + \beta_{ZK} Z_{JK} + e_{JK} \\
  B_{J} & = \beta_{ZJ} Z_{J} + e_{J} \\
  e_{IA} & \sim \text{Normal}(0, p_{IA}) \\  
  e_{I} & \sim \text{Normal}(0,1) \\
  e_{JK} & \sim \text{Normal}(0, p_{JK}) \\
  e_{J} & \sim \text{Normal}(0,1)
\end{aligned}
\]


(a)








\[
\begin{aligned}
  O_{RPUV} & := f_{C}(O^{sc}_{RPUV}, C) \\

  O^{cp}_{RPUV} & := f_{O}(D_{RPUV}) \\
